paragraphs.name: b4fa
paragraphs.text: He came back from deployment and we moved in together at a military base. We bought a car together and put both of our incomes in a joint account.

paragraphs.name: 56a6
paragraphs.text: By my senior year of college, I was working 50–55 hours per week and had socked away quite a bit of money. My college tuition was paid by scholarship, so I graduated with no loans. I was lucky.

paragraphs.name: 71f0
paragraphs.text: My ex-husband did not care that his financial decisions affected me as well.

paragraphs.name: bbd9
paragraphs.text: He overdrew our account that same day. I fought back humiliated tears at the credit union as I emptied our change jar to put our account back in the black. When I divorced him, I stayed in the same house (in separate bedrooms) because I couldn’t afford rent in upstate New York on my salary and had no savings for a hotel. Our final joint tax return went towards paying our divorce fees. In some ways, I was lucky because we had nothing to split and I could use the free law service on the base. I left my marriage with no savings, credit card debt, and the determination that I would never let another partner’s potential financial problems put me in that situation again.

virtuals.subtitle: You’ll drive yourself crazy with the chicken egg, doubt vs sabotage scenario. We all just keep learning and hoping for the best.

965d7886a6ec.title: Good for you for getting out when things don’t work.

paragraphs.name: 4bfc
paragraphs.text: Good for you for getting out when things don’t work. I hope you find someone that makes you happy someday. As for money, I think people can keep things separate while still being transparent. Like opening a joint account for common bills, but each of you knows that you also have a separate savings account. I think the conversation is more important…

paragraphs.name: 75bf
paragraphs.text: My wife and I trust that our marriage will last forever. I certainly don’t have any inclination on leaving her and one of the first things I showed her after we got engaged was my credit history. An analogy to this might be the full blood checkups I demanded before becoming serious and moving in with each other.

f49931de25da.title: As a financial advisor, this is an area that I tackle on a regular basis with my clients who are…

paragraphs.name: f033
paragraphs.text: As a financial advisor, this is an area that I tackle on a regular basis with my clients who are couples…even some who have been together for 30+ years! There are ways to combine some of your money, but not all…commit to joint goals, but maintain independence. Too often I see (primarily) women who stay completely ignorant of how their family finances…

9909119a71da.title: You sound like an angry ex wife.

paragraphs.text: You sound like an angry ex wife. Maybe some cool down time would be a good idea before writing this post.

91d54f659092.title: I worked for years to pull myself out of debt after my divorce.

paragraphs.name: 02ef
paragraphs.text: I worked for years to pull myself out of debt after my divorce. I know the pain and humiliation. My ex sounds a lot like yours. I am still paying, despite having all of the debt paid off because it’s taking forever for my credit score to come up. I’m trying to purchase a home for myself, but despite having no credit card debt, and no collections, I…

4d073f0f11f1.title: If a person enters a relationship planning for failure, it will fail.

paragraphs.name: 2c94
paragraphs.text:
If a person enters a relationship planning for failure, it will fail.
You are not committed to the relationship if you have planned a way out.

paragraphs.name: 72ce
paragraphs.text: Alas, neither did mine. It is especially frustrating when you are trying to build something together only to find your so-called partner is more like dead weight. He developed this nasty habit of only working when he absolutely had to. The moment HIS bills were paid — not OURS or anything having to do with the extra expenses I took on — he would quit…

The red flags were there and you ignored them and paid the price. Maybe you believed that you could “change him”. We keep telling women that its their right to any choices they make…

paragraphs.text: Financial security should give you peace of mind. “Financial infidelity” is specious for me and you are blessed to have the safety net. Keep the faith :)

paragraphs.text: The shared account is something i will never understand, to me it always felt like a way of controlling your significant other and i dont believe you can have an honest relationship where you dont trust them enough to let the other spend their own money.

virtuals.subtitle: I don’t know what the answer is — but maintaining a level of self-sufficiency and independence has to be non-negotiable.

1bf37be8e2f0.title: Stories like this contribute to my happy singlehood.

content.subtitle: I don’t know what the answer is — but maintaining a level of self-sufficiency and independence has to be non-negotiable.

paragraphs.text: Stories like this contribute to my happy singlehood. Honestly, I just can’t see the risk-reward benefit, and I’ve always been happiest in solitude.
I don’t know what the answer is — but maintaining a level of self-sufficiency and independence has to be non-negotiable.
